content.description:
Start with left hand in a good low jug and right hand in a high jug, (there is also a right foot cam), climb straight up and pull the fun top out. 

  Try to stay away from the chossy blocks to the right of the climb as they may rip off in your face.
content.protection:
There is a steep ramp like boulder at the landing that makes spotting the top out important though the holds are good.  

  At least 1 pad and a spotter.
content.location:
Located on the overhang directly to the right of the V0 down climb, There is a space on the overhang to the left of the chossy blocks that goes up on good pockets and crimps. 

  Down climb on the V0 to the left

content.description: Super awkward route. However it was really fun. I don't know if it's been climbed yet but I figured I'd put in some information to help further develop the area.
Fallow the really easy jug pockets up the right side of the slab to the top.
content.location:
Located on the right side of the backside slab. 

  This is also the down climb for all the other routes on the boulder.

content.description:
Climb up the middle of the diamond shaped slab on the back of the boulder. There is a good step up on to the slab than it's easy climbing on perfect pockets to the top. 

  To make this more interesting climb with no hands (forearms allowed).
content.location:
This route is on the slab on the backside of the boulder with four or five perfectly spaced pockets up the middle. 

  Down climb the V0 to the right

content.description:
This is a large sandstone slab located on the left of the trail to the top of Sorenson Point. The slab side is about 25ft high and should offer two moderate looking highball problems. On the backside, the boulder is much steeper and several harder possibilities exist.  

  Please add any specific routes if you know them and if you know of the actual name of this boulder, please let me know.
